Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   [**6-1**] Events:
   -tachypnea and wheezing with position changes to 40
s and 50
   Per previous MICU admission note:
   76 YO M w/history of parkinson's disease, COPD, afib, hearing loss,
   urinary retention w/indwelling foley, and recent admission for
   aspiration pneumonia admitted today w/complaint of worsening cough and
   low grade temp. Patient was admitted to [**Hospital1 19**] [**5-9**] - [**5-13**] and treated w/a
   2 week course of linezolid and zosyn which ended on [**5-23**]. Since then
   patient has had a worsening cough but reports no fever (NH reports temp
   - unclear how high). Patient denies SOB, chest pain, or any other
   symptoms. Patient given Vanco and Zosyn in ED.
   .
   In the emergency department he was found to have low grade temp - 100,
   100.2, tachycardic to 110, tachypnic to 40 and 93% on 3L. He was given
   vanc and zosyn as well as nebs in the ED and admitted to the medical
   floor. On the floor, he was being treated for viral pneumonia.
   Antibiotics were held and he was ordered for q6 nebs. He subsequently
   triggered this evening for tachypnea to the 40s, though has maintained
   his sats in the high 90s on 4L nasal cannula. ABG was 7.43/44/192. He
   was given solumedrol 125mg IV, zosyn, vanco, nebs x 2. Transfer to MICU
   was requested for closer monitoring.
   .
   On arrival to the MICU, the patient denies respiratory distress. Per
   report, he has been having diarrhea recently. His main concern is
   locating his call bell and having the light turned out. He denies LH,
   dizziness, chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain.
   Allergies:
   Sulfa (Sulfonamides)
   Unknown;
   Hydantoins
   Unknown;

   Unknown;

   *Also written for ciprofloxacin 500mg Q12H

   Physical Examination
   Gen: frail elderly male, appears anxious, resting tremor
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. very dry MM, OP clear.
   CV: tachy, normal S1, S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
   Chest: No chest wall deformities. tachypneic and using accessory
   muscles to breath. Diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing, poor air
   movement, worse on L>R.
   Abd: +PEG tube in place without any surrounding erythema, +BS, Soft,
   non-tender, non-distended. No HSM or tenderness.
   Ext: Cachectic, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema. Radial and DP pulses
   2+, contractures of the hands and feet
   Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.5/32.9/1.2, Ca++:8.2 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0
   mg/dL, PO4:4.2 mg/dL
   UCx [**5-31**]: Pnd
   BCx [**5-31**]: Pnd
   C. Diff. Stool Toxin [**5-31**]: Neg.
   UA: sm leuk, lg bld, nitr neg, 30 prot, tr ket, few bac, [**12-26**] RBC,
   21-50 WBC, 0-2 epi
   Imaging: [**5-31**] CXR #1: Marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm as
   well as persistent moderate left pleural effusion and associated
   atelectasis remain. There is slightly improved aeration of the left
   upper lobe. The right lung remains clear. The cardiomediastinal
   silhouette is stable. Severe rightward scoliosis limits evaluation.
   Gas-filled loops of colon are again noted.
   IMPRESSION: Slightly improved aeration at the left lung apex with
   decreased pleural effusion. No definite evidence of pneumonia.
   .
   [**5-31**] CXR #2: difficult to interpret [**3-10**] marked elevation of L
   hemidiaphragm, no obvious significant change
   .
   [**5-31**] CT chest:
   1) Persisting dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe, likely
   from aspiration.
   2) Prominent elevation of the left hemidiaphragm without diaphragmatic
   defect.
   3) Two small 4- to 5-mm ground-glass nodules in the right middle lobe
   (3:32) which appear likely unchanged compared to the CT torso of
   [**2165-10-24**], however followup in one year by CT is recommended.
   4) Only partially imaged on today's study is a approximately 4 cm
   apparent cystic mass anterior to the IVC at the level of the filter
   placement. This lesion is not well characterized on this study, though
   is most suggestive of a GI duplication cyst. It has not changed
   significantly from the CT of [**2165-11-9**].
   6) 2 cm indeterminate left renal lesion which is not well characterized
   by non-contrast CT. Evaluation by MR is recommended if the patient is a
   potiental surgical candidate. Otherwise, a 6 month follow-up CT could
   be performed.
   7) Severe scoliosis.
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to
   interpret b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm.
   - Will stop vanco/zosyn and observe patient
   - will switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Low grade Fever: patient w/low grade temps on previous ED and on the
   floor. Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley).
   Abdomen benign. Temp is low grade - possible pt w/viral etiology. No
   skin lesions. CDiff possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of
   diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - remove foley, condom catheter
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code, confirmed with patient and attempted to contact
   healthcare proxy.  Pt. clear he wishes to be intubated even if it means
   he may never wean off machine.
   #. Dispo: ICU for now
   #. Communication: Nephew [**Name (NI) 209**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1801**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling foley catheter, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia. He was admitted to the ICU for closer monitoring due to tachypnea and worsening cough.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 98°F (36.7°C)
* Heart rate: 68 bpm
* Blood pressure: 112/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* ABG: pH 7.43, PaCO2 44 mmHg, PaO2 192 mmHg

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Frail elderly male with an anxious appearance
* Resting tremor
* Tachypneic with diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing
* Poor air movement, worse on the left side
* Cachectic with no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 2.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 105 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 26 mEq/L
* Sodium: 143 mEq/L
* Potassium: 107 mEq/L
* Glucose: 169 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies reveal:

* CXR: Marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm with persistent moderate left pleural effusion and associated atelectasis
* CT chest: Dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe, likely due to aspiration; two small ground-glass nodules in the right middle lobe; approximately 4-cm cystic mass anterior to the IVC; and 2-cm indeterminate left renal lesion

The patient's diagnosis and plan are:

* Tachypnea: Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly triggered by unresolved pneumonia, or viral URI
* Low-grade fever: Possible sources include lung, urine, or viral etiology
* Tachycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable, and possibly due to low-grade temp, anxiety, or albuterol nebs
* UTI: Continue ciprofloxacin
* Parkinson's disease: Continue current medications
* COPD: Continue nebulizers
* Anemia: Guaiac stools, follow Hct, and type and screen sent
* Afib: Continue amiodarone, hold anticoagulation as per Hx of GI bleeding
* Foley catheter: Remove and replace with condom catheter

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Due to COPD exacerbation or pneumonia
* Sepsis: Due to UTI or pneumonia
* Dehydration: Due to tachypnea, tachycardia, or low-grade fever
* GI bleeding: Due to anticoagulation or Parkinson's disease medications
* Renal failure: Due to dehydration or underlying kidney disease
* Cardiovascular complications: Due to atrial fibrillation or hypertension

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling foley catheter, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia. He was initially admitted to the medical floor and treated with antibiotics for viral pneumonia, but was later transferred to the MICU due to worsening tachypnea and wheezing. The patient is currently receiving oxygen therapy via a high-flow nasal cannula and has been given solumedrol, zosyn, and vancomycin. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.6°C, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 112/55 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tachypnea and wheezing may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen if not managed promptly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's recent admission for aspiration pneumonia and current symptoms of tachypnea and wheezing suggest that pneumonia may be a persistent or recurring issue.
3. Sepsis: The patient's tachycardia, tachypnea, and low-grade fever may indicate sepsis, which could progress to septic shock if not recognized and treated early.
4. Dehydration: The patient's fluid balance data shows a negative balance of 659 mL, which may indicate dehydration.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's recent diarrhea and presence of a PEG tube may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia may indicate cardiovascular complications, such as atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response or cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Skin Complications: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of skin breakdown and infection.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's nutritional status is not well-documented, but his recent admission and current medical condition may indicate malnutrition.
9. Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and presence of an indwelling foley catheter may indicate a urinary tract infection, which could be a source of sepsis.
10. Medication-Related Complications: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, steroids, and anticoagulants, which may interact with each other or cause adverse effects.

   UA: sm leuk, lg bld, nitr neg, 30 prot, tr ket, few bac, [**12-26**] RBC,
   21-50 WBC, 0-2 epi
   Imaging: [**5-31**] CXR #1: Marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm as
   well as persistent moderate left pleural effusion and associated
   atelectasis remain. There is slightly improved aeration of the left
   upper lobe. The right lung remains clear. The cardiomediastinal
   silhouette is stable. Severe rightward scoliosis limits evaluation.
   Gas-filled loops of colon are again noted.
   IMPRESSION: Slightly improved aeration at the left lung apex with
   decreased pleural effusion. No definite evidence of pneumonia.
   .
   [**5-31**] CXR #2: my read: difficult to interpret [**3-10**] marked elevation of L
   hemidiaphragm, no obvious significant change
   .
   [**5-31**] CT chest:
   1) Persisting dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe, likely
   from aspiration.
   2) Prominent elevation of the left hemidiaphragm without diaphragmatic
   defect.
   3) Two small 4- to 5-mm ground-glass nodules in the right middle lobe
   (3:32) which appear likely unchanged compared to the CT torso of
   [**2165-10-24**], however followup in one year by CT is recommended.
   4) Only partially imaged on today's study is a approximately 4 cm
   apparent cystic mass anterior to the IVC at the level of the filter
   placement. This lesion is not well characterized on this study, though
   is most suggestive of a GI duplication cyst. It has not changed
   significantly from the CT of [**2165-11-9**].
   6) 2 cm indeterminate left renal lesion which is not well characterized
   by non-contrast CT. Evaluation by MR is recommended if the patient is a
   potiental surgical candidate. Otherwise, a 6 month follow-up CT could
   be performed.
   7) Severe scoliosis.
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna, recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI. Completed
   14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to interpret
   b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm.
   - continue vanco/zosyn, cipro
   - will switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Fever: patient w/low grade temps on previous ED and on the floor.
   Possible sources lung vs urine (indwelling foley). Abdomen benign. Temp
   is low grade - possible pt w/viral etiology. No skin lesions. CDiff
   possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - foley changed
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code
   #. Dispo: ICU for now
   #. Communication: Nephew [**Name (NI) 209**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1801**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling Foley catheter, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia. The patient was initially treated with a 2-week course of linezolid and zosyn, which ended on May 23rd. Since then, the patient has had a worsening cough but reports no fever.

The patient was admitted to the medical floor and treated for viral pneumonia. Antibiotics were held, and the patient was ordered to receive q6 nebs. However, the patient triggered for tachypnea in the evening, and the ABG showed no evidence of hypoxia. The patient was given solumedrol, zosyn, vanco, and nebs x2. The patient was subsequently transferred to the MICU for closer monitoring.

The patient's main concern is locating his call bell and having the light turned off. He denies respiratory distress, dizziness, chest pain, SOB, or abdominal pain. The patient has a history of diarrhea and was given ciprofloxacin.

The patient's vital signs are:

* T: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* HR: 68 bpm (53-100 bpm)
* BP: 112/55 mmHg (70-113/55-92 mmHg)
* RR: 25 inspirations per minute (23-59 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: frail elderly male, appears anxious, resting tremor
* HEENT: normal
* CV: tachycardic, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
* Chest: tachypneic, using accessory muscles to breathe, diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing, poor air movement, worse on the left side
* Abd: soft, non-tender, non-distended, no HSM or tenderness
* Ext: cachectic, no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema, radial and DP pulses 2+, contractures of the hands and feet
* Skin: no stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 2.8-4.0 K/uL
* Hct: 30.2-28.8%
* Plt: 105-114 K/uL
* Cr: 0.9-1.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 169-180 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.5/32.9/1.2, Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL, PO4: 4.2 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR #1: marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm, persistent moderate left pleural effusion, and associated atelectasis
* CXR #2: difficult to interpret, marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm, no obvious significant change
* CT chest: dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe, likely from aspiration; two small ground-glass nodules in the right middle lobe; approximately 4-cm apparent cystic mass anterior to the IVC; 2-cm indeterminate left renal lesion

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Continue vanco/zosyn, cipro
* Switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x5 days
* Standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
* Continue guiafenesin
* Sputum sample if patient able
* Chest PT if patient tolerates
* Follow-up blood culture, urine culture
* Follow-up c diff
* Sputum CX if able
* Foley changed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening COPD exacerbation
* Sepsis or septic shock due to UTI or pneumonia
* Dehydration due to diarrhea or vomiting
* Anemia due to GI bleeding or other causes
* Thromboembolic events due to immobility or other factors
* Cardiovascular events due to atrial fibrillation or other cardiac conditions
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to aspirin or other medications
* Worsening of Parkinson's disease symptoms due to medication changes or other factors

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   potiental surgical candidate. Otherwise, a 6 month follow-up CT could
   be performed.
   7) Severe scoliosis.
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna, recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI. Completed
   14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to interpret
   b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm.
   - continue vanco/zosyn, cipro
   - will switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Fever: patient w/low grade temps on previous ED and on the floor.
   Possible sources lung vs urine (indwelling foley). Abdomen benign. Temp
   is low grade - possible pt w/viral etiology. No skin lesions. CDiff
   possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - foley changed
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code
   #. Dispo: ICU for now
   #. Communication: Nephew [**Name (NI) 209**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1801**]
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling Foley catheter, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia. He was initially treated with a 2-week course of linezolid and zosyn, but has since developed worsening cough and low-grade temperature. He was admitted to the medical floor and later transferred to the MICU due to tachypnea and wheezing.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Tachypneic with wheezing, using accessory muscles to breathe, and diffuse coarse breath sounds.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, with a sinus rhythm.
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.
* Extremities: Cachectic, with no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
* Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.
* Laboratory results: Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL, and an elevated white blood cell count.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and wheezing may progress to respiratory failure if not managed promptly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's recent aspiration pneumonia may not have fully resolved, and the development of new infiltrates on chest radiography suggests ongoing lung injury.
3. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade temperature and tachycardia may be indicative of sepsis, particularly given his recent antibiotic use and indwelling Foley catheter.
4. Dehydration: The patient's tachycardia and decreased urine output may indicate dehydration, which needs to be addressed promptly.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed, particularly given his history of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as stroke or arrhythmias.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent antibiotic use may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation.

Plan:

1. Continue vancomycin and zosyn for pneumonia and sepsis.
2. Switch to prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
3. Continue albuterol and atrovent nebs for bronchodilation.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, including oxygen saturation and respiratory rate.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status, including heart rate and blood pressure.
6. Manage the patient's anemia with iron supplements and blood transfusions as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status, including stool output and electrolyte levels.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and adjust antibiotics as needed.
9. Consider further imaging studies, such as a computed tomography (CT) scan, to evaluate the patient's lung and liver function.

Summary:

The patient is a frail elderly male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchitis, and emphysema. He has been experiencing tachypnea and wheezing with position changes, which triggered his return to the ICU. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98°C, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 112/55 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy through a high-flow nebulizer and has a peak flow of 100%. His physical examination reveals a resting tremor, dry mucous membranes, and diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing.

The patient has a history of allergies to sulfa, hydantoins, trimethadione, phenacemide, barbiturates, and primidone, as well as unknown allergies to gadolinium-containing agents and Mysoline. He has received antibiotics, including piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin, and is receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 2.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 105 K/uL. His blood urea nitrogen is 46 mg/dL, and his creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. His glucose level is 169 mg/dL, and his electrolyte levels are within normal range.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and wheezing may indicate respiratory failure, which could lead to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory symptoms and history of COPD may increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of antibiotics and unknown allergies may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
4. Pressure ulcers: The patient's frailty and immobility may increase his risk of developing pressure ulcers.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's history of COPD and respiratory symptoms may indicate malnutrition, which could worsen his respiratory status.
6. DVT: The patient's immobility and history of COPD may increase his risk of developing deep vein thrombosis.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient's history of antibiotics and unknown allergies may increase his risk of developing stress ulcer.
8. VAP: The patient's history of antibiotics and unknown allergies may increase his risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory status, blood pressure, and electrolyte levels, as well as provide aggressive treatment for his respiratory symptoms and potential infections.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/55 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 2.8 K/uL. The platelet count is 105 K/uL. The patient's renal function is mildly impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL. The patient's glucose level is 169 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the absence of assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other systems. The patient's respiratory support includes high-flow nasal oxygen therapy, and the patient is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's unknown allergies to various medications, including sulfa, hydantoins, and barbiturates, may increase the risk of allergic reactions. Additionally, the patient's mild anemia and impaired renal function may predispose them to sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and bronchitis may lead to respiratory failure, particularly if the patient experiences an acute exacerbation.
3. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobilization and history of chronic disease may increase the risk of VTE.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulant therapy, including heparin sodium, may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's unknown allergies and use of antibiotics, including piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin, may increase the risk of infection.
6. Metabolic complications: The patient's impaired glucose regulation and mild anemia may lead to metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
7. Neurologic complications: The patient's unknown allergies and use of medications, including anticonvulsants and barbiturates, may increase the risk of neurologic complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination to identify any potential complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   [**6-1**] Events:
   -tachypnea and wheezing with position changes to 40
s and 50
   Per previous MICU admission note:
   76 YO M w/history of parkinson's disease, COPD, afib, hearing loss,
   urinary retention w/indwelling foley, and recent admission for
   aspiration pneumonia admitted today w/complaint of worsening cough and
   low grade temp. Patient was admitted to [**Hospital1 19**] [**5-9**] - [**5-13**] and treated w/a
   2 week course of linezolid and zosyn which ended on [**5-23**]. Since then
   patient has had a worsening cough but reports no fever (NH reports temp
   - unclear how high). Patient denies SOB, chest pain, or any other
   symptoms. Patient given Vanco and Zosyn in ED.
   .
   In the emergency department he was found to have low grade temp - 100,
   100.2, tachycardic to 110, tachypnic to 40 and 93% on 3L. He was given
   vanc and zosyn as well as nebs in the ED and admitted to the medical
   floor. On the floor, he was being treated for viral pneumonia.
   Antibiotics were held and he was ordered for q6 nebs. He subsequently
   triggered this evening for tachypnea to the 40s, though has maintained
   his sats in the high 90s on 4L nasal cannula. ABG was 7.43/44/192. He
   was given solumedrol 125mg IV, zosyn, vanco, nebs x 2. Transfer to MICU
   was requested for closer monitoring.
   .
   On arrival to the MICU, the patient denies respiratory distress. Per
   report, he has been having diarrhea recently. His main concern is
   locating his call bell and having the light turned out. He denies LH,
   dizziness, chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain.

   UCx [**5-31**]: Pnd
   BCx [**5-31**]: Pnd
   C. Diff. Stool Toxin [**5-31**]: Neg.
   UA: sm leuk, lg bld, nitr neg, 30 prot, tr ket, few bac, [**12-26**] RBC,
   21-50 WBC, 0-2 epi
   Imaging: [**5-31**] CXR #1: Marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm as
   well as persistent moderate left pleural effusion and associated
   atelectasis remain. There is slightly improved aeration of the left
   upper lobe. The right lung remains clear. The cardiomediastinal
   silhouette is stable. Severe rightward scoliosis limits evaluation.
   Gas-filled loops of colon are again noted.
   IMPRESSION: Slightly improved aeration at the left lung apex with
   decreased pleural effusion. No definite evidence of pneumonia.
   .
   [**5-31**] CXR #2: difficult to interpret [**3-10**] marked elevation of L
   hemidiaphragm, no obvious significant change
   .
   [**5-31**] CT chest:
   1) Persisting dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe, likely
   from aspiration.
   2) Prominent elevation of the left hemidiaphragm without diaphragmatic
   defect.
   3) Two small 4- to 5-mm ground-glass nodules in the right middle lobe
   (3:32) which appear likely unchanged compared to the CT torso of
   [**2165-10-24**], however followup in one year by CT is recommended.
   4) Only partially imaged on today's study is a approximately 4 cm
   apparent cystic mass anterior to the IVC at the level of the filter
   placement. This lesion is not well characterized on this study, though
   is most suggestive of a GI duplication cyst. It has not changed
   significantly from the CT of [**2165-11-9**].
   6) 2 cm indeterminate left renal lesion which is not well characterized
   by non-contrast CT. Evaluation by MR is recommended if the patient is a
   potiental surgical candidate. Otherwise, a 6 month follow-up CT could
   be performed.
   7) Severe scoliosis.
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to
   interpret b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm.
   - Will stop vanco/zosyn and observe patient
   - will switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Low grade Fever: patient w/low grade temps on previous ED and on the
   floor. Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley).
   Abdomen benign. Temp is low grade - possible pt w/viral etiology. No
   skin lesions. CDiff possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of
   diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - remove foley, condom catheter
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code, confirmed with patient and attempted to contact
   healthcare proxy.  Pt. clear he wishes to be intubated even if it means
   he may never wean off machine.
   #. Dispo: ICU for now
   #. Communication: Nephew [**Name (NI) 209**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1801**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:

   Code status: Full code

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to
   interpret b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm.
   - Will stop vanco/zosyn and observe patient
   - will switch to prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates

   floor. Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley).

   skin lesions. CDiff possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of
   diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - remove foley, condom catheter
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code, confirmed with patient and attempted to contact
   healthcare proxy.  Pt. clear he wishes to be intubated even if it means

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling foley catheter, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia, was readmitted to the ICU due to worsening cough and low-grade fever. He was initially treated with vancomycin and zosyn in the emergency department and was subsequently admitted to the medical floor, where he was treated for viral pneumonia and antibiotics were held.

Upon admission to the ICU, the patient was found to be tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, but his oxygen saturation remained high at 100%. He was given solu-medrol, zosyn, and vancomycin, and was transferred to the ICU for closer monitoring.

The patient's main concern is locating his call bell and having the light turned out. He denies respiratory distress, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and dizziness. His physical examination reveals a frail elderly male with an anxious appearance, a resting tremor, and coarse breath sounds with wheezing in the chest.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and creatinine, but the patient's kidney function is stable. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his glucose level is slightly elevated. Imaging studies reveal a persistent moderate left pleural effusion and atelectasis, as well as a small 4- to 5-mm ground-glass nodule in the right middle lobe.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Tachypnea: likely due to COPD exacerbation, possibly triggered by unresolved pneumonia, but not hypoxic. ABG is reassuring, and the patient is not hypoxic.
2. Low-grade fever: possibly due to viral etiology, and the patient is being treated with antibiotics.
3. Tachycardia: possibly due to dehydration, anxiety, or albuterol nebs. The patient will be given IV fluids and monitored.
4. UTI: the patient will continue to receive ciprofloxacin.
5. Parkinson's disease: the patient will continue to receive his current medications.
6. COPD: the patient will continue to receive nebulizers.
7. Anemia: the patient's Hct is at baseline, and he has a history of GI bleeds. The patient will be monitored for GI bleeding and Hct levels.
8. Afib: the patient will continue to receive amiodarone, and anti-coagulation will be held due to his history of GI bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: the patient's tachypnea and wheezing could lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: the patient's low-grade fever and elevated white blood cell count could indicate a systemic infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: the patient's history of GI bleeds and anemia could increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Cardiovascular complications: the patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia could increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Pneumonia: the patient's persistent pleural effusion and atelectasis could increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
6. Urinary tract infection: the patient's indwelling foley catheter and history of UTI could increase his risk of developing a urinary tract infection.
7. Dehydration: the patient's tachycardia and elevated blood pressure could indicate dehydration, which could lead to serious complications if not managed properly.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, atrial fibrillation, hearing loss, urinary retention with an indwelling foley, and recent admission for aspiration pneumonia. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening cough and low-grade temperature. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but his symptoms have not improved. He is experiencing tachypnea, wheezing, and tachycardia, and is being treated with nebulizers and oxygen therapy. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he is still experiencing respiratory distress.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and wheezing may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen his condition if not addressed.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's recent admission for aspiration pneumonia and the presence of a persistent moderate left pleural effusion and associated atelectasis on the CXR suggest that pneumonia may still be a concern.
3. COPD exacerbation: The patient's history of COPD and the presence of bronchitis and emphysema on the CXR suggest that COPD exacerbation may be a potential complication.
4. DVT: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of a moderate left pleural effusion on the CXR suggest that DVT may be a potential complication.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's history of Parkinson's disease and the presence of a 4-cm apparent cystic mass anterior to the IVC at the level of the filter placement on the CT chest suggest that GI bleeding may be a potential complication.
6. Renal insufficiency: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of a 2-cm indeterminate left renal lesion on the CT chest suggest that renal insufficiency may be a potential complication.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's history of Parkinson's disease and the presence of a low BMI suggest that malnutrition may be a potential complication.

These potential complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's condition in the ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to
   interpret b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm. - will switch to prednisone
   60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Low grade Fever: patient w/low grade temps on previous ED and on the
   floor. Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley).
   Abdomen benign. Temp is low grade - possible pt w/viral etiology. No
   skin lesions. CDiff possibility given recent Abx, although no Hx of
   diarrhea.
   - abx as above
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - follow-up c diff
   - sputum CX if able
   - foley replaced
   # Tacycardia: Clinically dehydrated, BP stable. EKG shows sinus
   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # Bradycardia:  Patient with sinus brady on ekg, no chest pain, trops
   negative.  Possible urinary retention/pharmacologic (cipro).
   - Cont. to monitor, EKG in AM.
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code, confirmed with patient and attempted to contact
   healthcare proxy.  Pt. clear he wishes to be intubated even if it means
   he may never wean off machine.
   #. Dispo: ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, chronic indwelling foley, and recent aspiration pneumonia. He was readmitted to the ICU with tachypnea, low-grade fever, and tachycardia. His current medications include linezolid, zosyn, and albuterol. He has a positive MRSA screen and C. diff stool toxin, and his CT chest shows persistent dependent consolidation in the left lower lobe and a cystic mass anterior to the IVC.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's recent aspiration pneumonia may recur, especially with decreased cough and normal WBC count.
2. COPD Exacerbation: The patient's underlying COPD may worsen, leading to increased respiratory distress.
3. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient's indwelling foley and positive MRSA screen increase the risk of UTI.
4. C. diff Colitis: The patient's positive C. diff stool toxin and recent antibiotics increase the risk of C. diff colitis.
5. Dehydration: The patient's tachycardia and low-grade fever may be indicative of dehydration, which could worsen his condition.
6. Bradycardia: The patient's sinus bradycardia may be a sign of underlying cardiac issues or medication side effects.
7. Anemia: The patient's low Hct may indicate anemia, which could worsen his condition.
8. GI Bleeding: The patient's history of GI bleeds increases the risk of further bleeding, especially with his current medications.
9. Pneumonia: The patient's positive C. diff stool toxin and recent antibiotics increase the risk of pneumonia.
10. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and positive C. diff stool toxin increase the risk of sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for MRSA and C. diff.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely for signs of worsening COPD exacerbation.
3. Replace the indwelling foley to reduce the risk of UTI.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medications as necessary.
5. Consider adding antifungal medication to the patient's regimen to prevent fungal infections.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely for signs of bradycardia or tachycardia.
7. Consider adding iron supplements to the patient's regimen to help treat anemia.
8. Monitor the patient's GI status closely for signs of bleeding or other complications.
9. Consider adding a stress ulcer prophylaxis to the patient's regimen to reduce the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Monitor the patient's overall condition closely for signs of worsening sepsis or other complications.

Summary:

The patient is a frail elderly male with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the ICU. He has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, sepsis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has undergone several interventions, including the replacement of his Foley catheter due to mild hematuria and good urine output with some clots. His chest X-ray remains unchanged, but there is some improvement in lung aeration. He has also been experiencing bradycardia, with a slow heart rate as low as 38 beats per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL. He has a positive C. difficile stool toxin and a MRSA screen, and his blood culture is pending.

The patient's physical examination reveals tachypnea, coarse breath sounds, and wheezing in the lungs. He has a PEG tube in place without any surrounding erythema, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. He has contractures of the hands and feet, and his skin is dry and has no signs of stasis dermatitis, ulcers, or scars.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of MRSA pneumonia and sepsis increases his risk of developing septic shock and multi-organ failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea, coarse breath sounds, and wheezing suggest respiratory failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest and death.
3. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function increases his risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's bradycardia and potential prolonged QT interval increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's positive C. difficile stool toxin and history of diarrhea increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
6. Skin breakdown: The patient's dry skin and contractures increase his risk of developing skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
7. Infection: The patient's positive MRSA screen and pending blood culture increase his risk of developing secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a frail elderly male with a confirmed diagnosis of MRSA, who has undergone a full code and has been admitted to the ICU. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 36.6°C, Tcurrent of 35.4°C, HR of 59 bpm, BP of 117/51 mmHg, RR of 23 inspirations per minute, and SpO2 of 100%.

The patient has been experiencing bradycardia overnight, with a slow heart rate as low as 38 bpm, and has been treated with heparin sodium for prophylaxis. The patient's respiratory support includes oxygen delivery via an aerosol-cool device, with an SpO2 of 100% and an ABG of 28/28.

The patient's physical examination reveals a frail elderly male with a resting tremor, dry mucous membranes, and tachypnea with diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing. The patient's abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with a PEG tube in place. The patient's GU system is notable for blood at the meatus, with some clots in the urine.

Laboratory results show a WBC count of 2.8, Hct of 30.2, and Plt of 105. The patient's Cr is 0.9, TropT is <0.01, and Glucose is 169. Other notable laboratory results include a PT/PTT/INR of 13.5/32.9/1.2, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T of 56/<0.01/<0.01, and Ca++/Mg++/PO4 of 8.2/2.0/2.0 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's diagnosis of MRSA, there is a risk of sepsis and septic shock.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea, diffuse coarse breath sounds, and wheezing may indicate respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's bradycardia and prolonged QT interval may indicate cardiac complications, such as torsades de pointes or cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's Cr level of 0.9 may indicate early signs of renal failure, which may require dialysis.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and altered nutrition may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as malnutrition, dehydration, or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Skin integrity issues: The patient's impaired skin integrity may lead to skin breakdown, pressure ulcers, or infections.
7. Pulmonary complications: The patient's COPD, bronchitis, and emphysema may lead to pulmonary complications, such as acute exacerbation, pneumonia, or respiratory failure.

Summary:

The patient, a frail elderly male, is a full code patient with a confirmed MRSA infection, positive blood cultures, and mild hematuria. He is experiencing bradycardia, with a heart rate as low as 38 bpm, and has a prolonged QT interval on his EKG. His respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 100% on aerosol-cool oxygen delivery. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchitis, and emphysema, but no acute exacerbation is present.

The patient's physical examination reveals a cachectic appearance, with a resting tremor and dry mucous membranes. His chest is tachypneic, with diffuse coarse breath sounds and wheezing, but no chest wall deformities are present. His abdominal examination is normal, with no tenderness or distension.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.9 K/uL, with a hemoglobin level of 27.0 g/dL and a platelet count of 114 K/uL. His serum creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his troponin-T level is less than 0.01 ng/mL. His blood glucose level is 139 mg/dL, and his calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels are within normal limits.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA infection and mild hematuria increase the risk of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's bradycardia and prolonged QT interval on his EKG increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including torsades de pointes or ventricular fibrillation.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and bronchitis increase the risk of respiratory failure, which could be exacerbated by his tachypnea and diffuse coarse breath sounds.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's alteration in nutrition and impaired skin integrity increase the risk of malnutrition, which could lead to further complications, including pressure ulcers and decreased wound healing.
5. DVT and pulmonary embolism: The patient's immobility and history of COPD increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism.
6. Stress ulcer: The patient's ICU stay and history of COPD increase the risk of stress ulcer, which could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and complications.
7. VAP: The patient's tracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which could lead to further respiratory complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a confirmed full code, who has developed MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) infection. They have been experiencing mild hematuria, good urine output, and passing some clots. The patient's CXR (Chest X-ray) remains unchanged, with possible better aeration. Overnight, the patient experienced bradycardia, with a heart rate as low as 38 beats per minute.

The patient has a history of allergies to various medications, including sulfa, hydantoins, and barbiturates. They have received antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and are being treated with various ICU medications, including lansoprazole, heparin sodium, and fibresource HN.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.4°C, heart rate of 59 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 117/51 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 100%. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and abnormal liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA infection and bradycardia increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's mild hematuria and decreased urine output may indicate AKI.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's COPD and possible respiratory acidosis may lead to respiratory failure.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's bradycardia and possible cardiac arrhythmias may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
5. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's impaired nutrition and altered gut function may lead to malnutrition and related complications.
6. Skin Integrity Issues: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
7. Infection Control: The patient's MRSA infection highlights the need for strict infection control measures to prevent further infections.
8. Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's fluid and electrolyte imbalance may lead to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and renal dysfunction.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's diarrhea and possible gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to complications such as dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
10. Cognitive and Neurological Impairment: The patient's altered mental status and possible neurological deficits may indicate cognitive and neurological impairment.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* MRSA screen: Positive

The patient's medical history includes Parkinson's disease, COPD, chronic indwelling foley, and recent aspiration pneumonia. He has also had a 14-day course of linezolid and zosyn completed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Recurrent aspiration pneumonia
* Viral URI
* COPD exacerbation
* Urinary tract infection
* C. difficile colitis
* MRSA infection
* Bradycardia and tachycardia
* Dehydration
* Anemia
* GI bleeding
* Parkinson's disease exacerbation

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Attempt to use BIPAP to assist with lung aeration
* Standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
* Continue guaifenesin

* Antibiotics for C. difficile and MRSA
* Follow-up blood cultures, urine culture, and C. difficile testing
* Monitoring for tachycardia and bradycardia
* Anemia management
* Parkinson's disease management
* COPD management

The patient's code status is full code, and he is currently being treated in the ICU.

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly trigerred by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. CXR difficult to
   interpret b/c of elevated hemidiaphragm. - will switch to prednisone
   60mg PO daily x 5 day course
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able

   floor. Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley).

   diarrhea.
   - abx as above

   tachycardia (Hx of afib but sinus during last admission as well). Could
   also be due to low grade temp, anxiety, albuterol nebs. Received 1L
   IVF.
   - will bolus another 500cc NS now
   - continue to monitor
   - expect tachycardia to improve as pt's breathing stabilizes
   # Bradycardia:  Patient with sinus brady on ekg, no chest pain, trops
   negative.  Possible urinary retention/pharmacologic (cipro).
   - Cont. to monitor, EKG in AM.
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - will guiac stools
   - follow Hct
   - type and screen sent
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI

   #. FEN: IVF as above, replete lytes prn, G tube feeds
   #. Access: PIV
   #. PPx: pneumoboots, SQH
   #. Code: full code, confirmed with patient and HCP.  Pt. clear he

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, COPD, and chronic indwelling foley catheter, who was re-admitted to the ICU from the floor with tachypnea. He has a confirmed MRSA infection and is experiencing mild hematuria with good urine output, but passing some clots. His CXR is unchanged, with possible better aerated lungs. He has been experiencing bradycardia, with a slow heart rate of 38 beats per minute, and has a prolonged QT interval on his EKG. He is also experiencing low-grade fever, likely due to a urinary tract infection, and has a history of anemia with GI bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA infection and low-grade fever increase the risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD exacerbation and tachypnea increase the risk of developing respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
3. Urinary retention: The patient's bradycardia and prolonged QT interval on his EKG increase the risk of developing urinary retention, which can lead to further complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia and history of GI bleeding increase the risk of developing further anemia and bleeding complications.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's bradycardia and prolonged QT interval on his EKG increase the risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
6. Infection: The patient's MRSA infection and low-grade fever increase the risk of developing further infections, such as pneumonia and bacteremia.
7. Renal failure: The patient's anemia and history of GI bleeding increase the risk of developing renal failure, which can lead to further complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Continue antibiotics for MRSA infection.
2. Administer IV fluids to treat dehydration and tachypnea.
3. Monitor for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure.
4. Continue nebulizers for COPD exacerbation.
5. Monitor for signs of urinary retention and anemia.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and EKG.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's anemia and GI bleeding.

* He has a positive MRSA screen and a C. difficile stool toxin, and is experiencing mild hematuria, good urine output, but passing some clots.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate of 59 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/51 mmHg.
* He has a sinus rhythm on EKG, but is experiencing bradycardia, with a heart rate as slow as 38 bpm.
* His oxygen saturation is 100% on aerosol-cool oxygen delivery.
* He has a Foley catheter in place, and is receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and other medications.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **UTI:** The patient has a history of indwelling foley and is experiencing hematuria and passing clots, which increases the risk of UTI.
2. **MRSA infection:** The patient has a positive MRSA screen, which increases the risk of MRSA infection, particularly in the setting of indwelling devices.
3. **C. difficile infection:** The patient has a positive C. difficile stool toxin, which increases the risk of C. difficile infection and potential complications such as colitis.
4. **Pneumonia:** The patient has a history of COPD and is experiencing tachypnea, which increases the risk of pneumonia.
5. **Dehydration:** The patient is clinically dehydrated, which increases the risk of dehydration-related complications such as electrolyte imbalance and hypotension.
6. **Bradycardia:** The patient's bradycardia may be related to urinary retention, pharmacologic effects, or other underlying conditions, and requires close monitoring.
7. **Anemia:** The patient has a low hemoglobin level, which may be related to GI bleeds or other underlying conditions, and requires further evaluation and management.
8. **Parkinson's disease:** The patient has a history of Parkinson's disease, which may be exacerbated by certain medications or conditions, and requires ongoing management.
9. **COPD exacerbation:** The patient has a history of COPD and is experiencing tachypnea, which increases the risk of COPD exacerbation and potential complications such as respiratory failure.

**Plan:**

* Continue antibiotics and other medications as ordered.
* Monitor the patient's vital signs, particularly his temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure.
* Continue to monitor his oxygen saturation and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary.
* Consider further evaluation and management of his UTI, MRSA infection, and C. difficile infection.
* Consider further evaluation and management of his pneumonia, dehydration, and bradycardia.
* Continue to manage his Parkinson's disease and COPD.
* Consider further evaluation and management of his anemia and potential GI bleeds.

   benign. No skin lesions. C. Diff toxin positive. Afebrile x 24 hours.
   - oral vancomycin for c. diff
   - cipro for UTI- 7 day course ( day one = [**5-31**])
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - sputum cx if able
   - foley replaced
   # Tacycardia/Bradycardia: Initally tachycardic on admission. Improved
   with IVF. On [**6-2**] developed bradycardia into the 30s. EKG showed sinus
   brady. No CP. Trops negative. Mentating throughout. Thought possibly to
   be secondary to urinary retention/pharmacologic (cipro). Resolved
   following placement of foley. Over last 24 hours HR 48-79.
   - Cont. to monitor
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # Parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic indwelling foley, and recent aspiration pneumonia. He was readmitted to the ICU with tachypnea, likely due to a COPD exacerbation or possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia. He has a low-grade fever, which is being treated with oral vancomycin for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) and ciprofloxacin for urinary tract infection (UTI). He also has bradycardia, which was resolved with the placement of a foley catheter. His anemia is stable, and he is being continued on his current medications for Parkinson's disease and COPD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and diffuse wheezing may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen with continued COPD exacerbation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's recent aspiration pneumonia and possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia may lead to pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status.
3. UTI: The patient's UTI may not be fully treated, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
4. C. diff colitis: The patient's C. diff infection may worsen, leading to colitis and potential complications such as perforation or abscesses.
5. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia may recur, particularly if his electrolytes and medication levels are not closely monitored.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, particularly if his GI bleeding is not adequately managed.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and recent tachycardia may indicate cardiovascular instability, which could lead to complications such as arrhythmias or heart failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, including oxygen saturation, vital signs, and ABG results.
2. Consider bronchodilators and corticosteroids to manage the patient's COPD exacerbation.
3. Continue antibiotic treatment for UTI and C. diff infection, and monitor for signs of sepsis or organ failure.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolytes and medication levels closely to prevent bradycardia or other adverse effects.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anemia and GI bleeding, and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, and consider adjusting his medications or electrolyte levels as necessary.

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly triggered by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. Initially treated
   with vanco/zosyn for? pneumonia however d/c
d [**6-2**] as pneumonia thought
   to be unlikely.  Tachypnea improved today.
   - Prednisone 60mg PO daily x 5 day course for ? COPD exacerbation.
   - Attempt to use BIPAP to assist with lung aeration
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT if pt tolerates
   # Low grade Fever: patient w/low grade temps in  ED and on the floor.
   Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley). Abdomen
   benign. No skin lesions. C. Diff toxin positive. Afebrile x 24 hours.
   - oral vancomycin for c. diff
   - cipro for UTI- 7 day course ( day one = [**5-31**])
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - sputum cx if able
   - foley replaced
   # Tacycardia/Bradycardia: Initally tachycardic on admission. Improved
   with IVF. On [**6-2**] developed bradycardia into the 30s. EKG showed sinus
   brady. No CP. Trops negative. Mentating throughout. Thought possibly to
   be secondary to urinary retention/pharmacologic (cipro). Resolved
   following placement of foley. Over last 24 hours HR 48-79.
   - Cont. to monitor
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # Parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and chronic indwelling foley catheter. He was readmitted to the ICU from the floor with tachypnea and was previously treated for aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on non-invasive ventilation (BIPAP) with a tidal volume of 720 mL and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99% and his ABG is 29 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's heart rate is 65-79 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 151/67 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient has a resting tremor and is on medication for Parkinson's disease.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a chronic indwelling foley catheter and has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete Blood Count (CBC): White blood cell count 2.8-5.2 K/uL, hemoglobin 9.6-30.1 g/dL, and platelet count 105-117 K/uL.
	+ Blood chemistry: Sodium 146-150 mEq/L, potassium 3.9-4.0 mEq/L, and creatinine 0.7-0.9 mg/dL.
	+ Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and diffuse wheezes suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's history of aspiration pneumonia and his current respiratory status suggest that he may be at risk for recurrent aspiration pneumonia.
3. Urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient's indwelling foley catheter and history of UTI suggest that he may be at risk for recurrent UTI.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and bradycardia suggest that he may be at risk for cardiovascular complications.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and his current gastrointestinal status suggest that he may be at risk for recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. C. difficile infection: The patient's C. difficile toxin-positive stool culture suggests that he may be at risk for C. difficile infection.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Non-invasive ventilation (BIPAP) to assist with lung aeration.
2. Prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
3. Albuterol and atrovent nebs to assist with bronchodilation.
4. Sputum sample to rule out pneumonia.
5. Chest PT to improve lung aeration.
6. Oral vancomycin for C. difficile infection.
7. Cipro for UTI.
8. Foley replacement.
9. Monitoring for cardiovascular complications.
10. Follow-up blood cultures and urine cultures to monitor for infection.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with ongoing respiratory support via non-invasive ventilation (BIPAP) due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) without acute exacerbation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, blood pressure of 151/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's respiratory support parameters are also stable, with a tidal volume of 720 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 14 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 40%. The patient's laboratory results show normal renal function, with a creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL, and normal electrolyte levels. The patient's white blood cell count is 5.2 K/uL, and their hemoglobin level is 9.6 g/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory support via non-invasive ventilation may not be sufficient to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation, potentially leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's recent antibiotic administration and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's COPD and respiratory support may increase the risk of pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure and other complications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's diarrhea and altered nutrition may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and other complications.
5. Skin integrity issues: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of skin breakdown and potential infections, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.
6. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia may be a sign of underlying cardiac dysfunction or electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrest and other complications.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's altered nutrition and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could exacerbate underlying medical conditions and increase the risk of complications.

These potential complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal systems, as well as their nutritional status and electrolyte balance.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 76 YO M w/ parkinsons, COPD, chronic indwelling foley,
   and recent aspiration pneumonia here re-admitted [**6-1**] from floor with
   tachypnea.
   # Tachypnea: Patient with underlying COPD. Not hypoxic but diffusely
   wheezy with poor air movement. ABG initially was reassuring with no
   evidence of hypoxia.  Likely COPD exacerbation, possibly triggered by
   unresolved pna though with decreased cough, normal WBC, and no outright
   fever, unlikely. Possible recurrent aspiration pneumonia, or viral URI.
   Completed 14d course of linezolid/zosyn 1 week ago. Initially treated
   with vanco/zosyn for? pneumonia however d/c
d [**6-2**] as pneumonia thought
   to be unlikely.  Tachypnea improved today.
   - continue Prednisone 60mg PO daily x 10 day course (day 5 of 10) for
   COPD exacerbation.
   - Attempt to use BIPAP to assist with lung aeration
   - standing albuterol and atrovent nebs q6 with albuterol prn q2
   - continue guiafenesin
   - sputum sample if patient able
   - chest PT
   # Low grade Fever: patient w/low grade temps in  ED and on the floor.
   Possible sources lung, however likely urine (indwelling foley). Abdomen
   benign. No skin lesions. C. Diff toxin positive. Afebrile x 48 hours.
   - oral vancomycin and IV flagyl for c. diff
   - cipro for UTI- 7 day course ( day one = [**5-31**])
   - follow-up blood cx, urine culture
   - sputum cx if able
   - foley replaced
   # Tacycardia/Bradycardia: Initally tachycardic on admission. Improved
   with IVF. On [**6-2**] developed bradycardia into the 30s. EKG showed sinus
   brady. No CP. Trops negative. Mentating throughout. Thought possibly to
   be secondary to urinary retention/pharmacologic (cipro). Resolved
   following placement of foley. Over last 24 hours HR 48-96.
   - Cont. to monitor
   # UTI: cont cipro
   # Parkinsons: continue current meds
   # COPD: continue nebulizers
   # Anemia: Hct at baseline, has Hx of GI bleeds
   - Hct stable
   # Afib: continue amiodarone, hold antiocoagulation as per Hx of GI
   bleeding.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2166-6-4**] 08:53 PM 60 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   16 Gauge - [**2166-5-31**] 11:50 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin sc tid
   Stress ulcer: Famotidine 20mg po bid
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: pending PT/OT eval. Screen for pulmonary rehab
